abstract.p: Letter from New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children executive director Anne Reiniger comments on August 10 article on studies showing no increase in child abuse since enactment of welfare-reform law in 1996

block.p: I am heartened by the results of two studies and recent data that show there is no increase in child abuse since enactment of the welfare reform law in 1996 (front page, Aug. 10). But it may be premature to draw conclusions about whether termination of public assistance to families will place children at risk. The true test will be when families reach the five-year lifetime limits for receiving welfare.

I am heartened by the results of two studies and recent data that show there is no increase in child abuse since enactment of the welfare reform law in 1996 (front page, Aug. 10). But it may be premature to draw conclusions about whether termination of public assistance to families will place children at risk. The true test will be when families reach the five-year lifetime limits for receiving welfare.

Some programs have already proved that child abuse can be reduced. The support of families through home-visiting programs like Healthy Families America, which offers more than 400 sites around the country, has reduced child abuse, improved child health and enhanced family self-sufficiency.
ANNE REINIGER Exec. Dir., New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children New York, Aug. 11, 2000
